I think from the communiques our sectorof the whole western front is the only one in which any fighting is being done. Everyone here seems mighty depressed about Russia. I cannot tellwhy because by then is silenceor if the yellow see fit to suggest all sorts of things what do they know.Russia has always been a mystery & will remainso to themwho do not understand Bethmann Hollweg's statement & reference has not come to light yet & I cannot believe it will now at any rate. They will give them submarines till the end of June to see what they can do.
Entry.104:
Bullecourt & Rouen areours. Will the Hun now start another big retirement because I haveheard from Artillery engineer & G.S.O.s that he will have to do so. Certainly the fighting about Bullecourt has been severe & the way the Hun has desperately attacked & counter attacked only strengthens me in that view.

Hollweg's statement was to have been made todaybut he has not made itup to date & nowthe papers say he will not make it till July.

Although I have not seen any actual figures the Hughesiteshave had a splendid victory in Australia. I do hope it means real genuine progress for Australia for we want to take our place properly as a grown daughter should & that will only happen while the best men guide our destinies & the best offering are certainly the party we know.
Entry.105:
The political news from Australia is decidedly encouraging & we were greatly pleased to know that the Soldiers vote actually put Mr Flynn in in an a electorate wherethe wretchedGerman vote actually displaced him. Ifeel now that dear old Australiahas partly redeemed itself for that awful vote in October last. Possibly she will never be able to wipethat right outbut at any rate a good strong capable government will be able to pilot us through the stormy seas & then at the proper time perhaps a new government of patriots will arise who will be at to do their best for the country & not to 
do
 the Country.

Still soldiers first if thesechaps will do their best to win the war then we shall be able to forgive them a lot. We all want to come home soon.
Entry.106: Was inundated today with old Australian newspapers so have decided to go right through them & bin all the useless ones. I thinktime the great bulk must have come by the boat because they turned up dated 1st January & the other papers were dated as far as March 10thso that there must be a screw loose somewhere. I must write home & ask themto send the weeklies & a strong daily welterimportant news in it. If I have to have this mail the postal people will not allow readdressed papers to follow me to another address. When I see the great bags of papers that arrive from , then I begin to realise what a great salethe papers must have in Australia. However weare a mostnaturally workinging system got at last 5 bags of papers from Australia per fortnight. Yet the about a paper faminein England.
Entry.107:
At last we are able to see a little daylight through our work & areable to think a bit clearly. I must candidly admit that for the past week my mind has been in a perfect fogwhich seems a silly thing to say for we have had nearly a week of easierwork. Stillit is so. I never feltso jolly tiredthat iI did not care to a single thing & have developedinto almosta pefect loafer. Itis mighty hard work being a loafer here.

Had a visit from Fred Walltonight. He said he was feeling a bithomesick (who does not?) and wanted cheering up. This is a new role for me butit is good to see people whom one knows apart from those with whom you work daily.

Our mess lately seems to be the retreat of Army medsout of work.Still it is good it is so.

May 19th

I have have beenworking jolly hardthe last few days with statisticsfor the unit's work during the strafe May 3rd-May 10th & I find that the the work done is really remarkablewhen closely analysed.

Just fancy we had 2670 wounded & we managed to operate on 524 of them which means that 20% of the admissions were surgically treated. In an ordinary surgical time such as the July strafe lost from 7-10% was the average while 10% was considered wonderfully. We only had 3 attached mento help& that for only part of the time. We averaged our 65 operations per day for the whole 8 days. Considering we had no day staff, no night staff but we justdid their best,it was a tributeto the splendid work that we actually got a bit of praisefrom the D.M.S.
Entry.108: army, a man who is sparing with his praise as he is sharp withhis tongue.
Entry.109: A very quiet day for us although we are supposed to be receiving. I do not believe that in the first 12 hours we received 6 patients. Our boys are holding the line splendidly but are anxiously awaiting to receive the relief for which they have waited so long. I dohope when they are all out that they will be given a goodposition in another part of the line. In the last Anzac orders is printed Sir Douglas Haig's despatch to General Birdwood & it containsthe highest promise. Certainly the Russian Guard & theWestern will have a different opinion of the stamina of the Australians after this fighting. It is something to be proud of in these parts where the Australian coat of armsfor the whole place is just swimmingwith the memoriesof the brilliant feats of our boys.
Entry.110:
Today the C.O. sprung a surprise packet on us, sentmeoff to Amiens in charge of 5 other officers for a day off. With the exception of the enforced10days absence when I had measlesthis is the first day off duty I have had since or before Christmas.

I was delighted that I had the trip because the trip up Grevillers was just when all that country,Pozieres, Le Sars, Courcelette, Warlencourt and other places hallowed by precious blood were a howling wilderness. Today nature has wakened & it all looks perfectlyallighted.The bright fresh green lushof spring has spread right over the land & it looks delightful. While even just great yawning shell holes & broken down trucks arecarpetted with the greenest undergrowth & they havelost all their ugly bruises.

We had a splendid day in Amiens & for the first time I saw the cathedral which was beautifully clear. The earliest date I noticed was 1632. It was but majestic. I want to see it again before describing.
Entry.111:
A wretchedly miserable day today for it has drizzled all day & everything is sloppy & muddy.

Tonight General Birdwood, Colonel Manifold & the A.D.C. dined with us and we had to parade ourselves because as the general had entertained our sisters we had to return the compliment. Eight of the sisters with 8 of the officers formed the dinner party. The rest of our staff were entertained in the sisters mess & as we numbered 38 all told it was a pretty big crowd.

I must say the General made himself just as decent as is possible for anyone to be & was glad he did so. He has a manner which is easy to understand & he has a wonderful memory for names & faces. As far as it was possible it was a delightful affairbut I hatea crowd & would have given a good deal to be absent. Still rigid etiquette wouldnot allow me my freedom.
Entry.112:
A glorious bright day quite a change from yesterday.

Had 2 interesting fellows in today. Two Australians captured by the Hun from the 4th division who have escaped, were taken to Lille where they were made to work. Say that Lille is just as in ordinary times. Plenty of people about & all doing some sort of work. They say also that they were shockingly fed, are all being kept in the front area as reprisal for our atrocities. They were fed on turnips & stuff something like thin soup stock. Had a piece of bread as big as a thumbnail. They also say that the Hun is very badly fed. One of them was shot as he returned by our chaps but that is not a surprising fact. They say they preferred death by being shot to death by starvation.

Rcd first letter portion of Australian mail today.
Entry.113:
The old Man's Birthday & Empire Day. For the very first time we toasted our Empire on active service. We just feel that we all want to be back by next Empire Day & that day then will be the finest and best day for the Empire celebrations we have ever had because we understand what Empire means now as we never did before the war.

Its good to be able to meet men from all over Great Britain & Ireland & also from the overseas & to feel we are one big family.

The Hunhas been busy todaywith his big guns & he'sbanging away but as per usual ofimportance happened. It is surprising how many duds are fired. It must cost a good deal in wasted ammunition.
Entry.114:
This morning Bell and I went for the first walk I have done over the fiercely foughtcountry which altogether summed up formedthe site of the great Somme battle.

We went in from Grevillers to the famous Loupert Wood following on the top of the Grevillers ridge. All round us to the south & east-west were places famous in history. Away on the skyline we could see High wood & Delville Wood. Closer to us were Le Sars & Coursellette . Still further to the left were Ligny & Thilloy & the famous Battle of Warlencourt. Directly in front by the Valley of the Ancre. Away to the right were Isles of Miraumont. The Loupert Wood we went right round & it was well worth a visit. The trenchs machine gun positions dugouts & shell holes were wonderful. Yes we had that awful sickening smell of dead men & horses. None who has not ever seen such sights & smelt them can realise & yet over all place thegolden & glorious sunshine to help us to forget the bloody struggle.

May 25

Today in the afternoon I was working hard when suddenly the C.O. informed me that I with 3 Sisters was to dine with the Lt. General Sir William Birdwood at Corps Headquarters. You can imagine my surprise. However, I had to grin & bear it & after going I was delighted to think I did. We had 4 generals in all as well as several highly placed staff officers. We dined in the open air & it was one of the most homelike meals I have had since I joined the service. If I amasked to go again I would jump at it. It just impressed me with an opinion I have that in the highest ranks of the service the best men are to found &the crusty majors & lieutenant Colonels are the ones which are the most objectionable.

We were back by 10 o'clock p.m. but it was a good night.
Entry.115:
What gloriously fine days there are just now. The sun in the middle of the day is so warm & yet the early mornings & the afternoons & evenings are delightfully cool.

Today is our receiving day & yet we are not overworked. Certainly our staff is being reduced & this is just what it should be. We are losing poor old Riley tomorrow & he is being replaced by a young chap who should have left Melbourne ages ago. He was wearing the uniform & hanging for dear life on to a cushy job in St Kilda Road Base Hospital. Riley was just a dear old chap & representative of that type of general family practitioner fast dyingout in Australia. He is one of the best informed & most polite men I have ever met. He certainly was a bit old & we carried him on our shoulders but still we did not mind that so long as he stayed. He thinks he is being pushed out.
Entry.116:
Today is Whitsunday & although feeling awfully weary I got up at 6.45 a.m. to go to church. I am afraid the explanation of weariness is simple. As yesterday was our receiving day & I did not anaesthetise during the day I naturally thought it would fall to my lot to work at night. The result was that I did not look at the list. Imagine my surprise when I found at between 12.30 & 1 a.m. that I was not on the list at all. 

Today the last of my mail arrived, 3 letters from Edna & one from Sister Roman. It was just the timingof fate that the mail should go out before I could possibly acknowledge receipt of the letters.

I have had a really lazy day but am going to bed at a respectable hour.
Entry.117:
A gloriously fine hot day today. For the first time since coming to this place our little C.C.S. is practically empty.

Received an invitation from Col Waters, town Major of Bapaume to help in a cricket match & so 8 of us are going up to play at 4 o'clock.

It seems quite strange to say it after the winter we have had but today it feels as hot as it used to do in dear old Australia.

It is exactly 2½ years today since I first sailed away from Australia & I once had the silly idea that the war would last 6 months. I am afraid I did not hold that idea very long. 

Have just received a cable from Edna saying she is needed for service & asking my approval. God keep her & bless her & let her arrive safely.
Entry.118:
Sent a cable to Edna saying I was delighted to know she had been accepted & also wanting to know when & where. I hope the censor will be good at the other end & will let her reply.

The match yesterday was an inglorious defeat for we only scored 28 & our opponents 73. In our second innings we retrieved & lost 4 for 73 but it was too late. However we have asked for our revenge on our own ground.

The news from the Italian front looks startlingly good. I have always placed morefaith in the Italians than may havebut it must be their ignorance of Italian physiography which makes them so impatient about the progress made. Truly the old Rusian is a broken reed at present but later on he should do well. What he wants is leadership & the Allies want to give their best.
Entry.119:
The Italian push still goes on & they are doing splendidly. It is great to think that our aviators& artillery are truly helping. It would be fine if the Italians take Trieste. The timetableis that the bulk of the population is Italian for to blowthat city to pieces would do a lot to counteract the needless blowing up of Albert & Arras. 

I wonder why we do not near Zeebrugge & these other coastal bases ofthe Germans where they could do good work if surrounded by a screen of torpedo boats. But if I get airing my strategy I shall probably get into trouble with Censor or G.H.Q. Sometimeshowever it slips out in spite of myself. Changing the French command encouraging but the nation trustsPetain & all asked who was thisNivellewho has come forward half French half English of the ' of Deal'.
Entry.120: How this month has gone. It is almost unbelievable that in this short while so much could have happened to us. I suppose it was the way day ran into nightfor the first half of the month that has made it go so quickly. We must have received 5000 patients & done over800 operations in this last month, a record which any C.C.S. has reason to be proud of considering in the last half we have admitted about 1000 & done not more than 150 operations. Tonight wehad a visitfrom the 5th Divisoinal folliesthe first show given to our unitsince we left . It was a might good turnout & I was glad we had a bumper house for they had gone to great pains to get the whole thing up.
Entry.121:
The C.O. returned today from a trip to Arras. He left yesterday with Col. Merricke& went up near Doullens. He says that considering how close it was to the actual line as compared with Albert it has got off wonderfully well.

Apparently the Germans made a dead set at the station for it is absolutely unrecognisable. Likewise the Cathedral and any conspicuous landmark. Still Arras did not get the amount of shelling Albert did but got more bombs.

The countryside about here just now is with field flowers. The buttercup has spread its yellow pall everywhere. The clover is gorgeous likewise the forgetmenot & the daisies. Truly what this country loses in winter it makes up for in spring & summer. It is a land of delight now.
Entry.122:
Quite a day of weird atmospheric conditons. Still the padre & I went out for a good walk & discovered a beautiful orchard. The gooseberries, black & red currants were well forward while the pears & apples were comingon well.

We have been greatly worried all day by a new German gun on this sector, an 4.5" Navalgun which fires very viciously & the shells had sight. It has fired all day but up to date has done no harm.

We got nota little suspense today when we found that our C.O. got a mention in Haig's despatches, one of the Imperial troops. This was rather good for he is in the Imperial list as distinct from the overseas troops. I was sorry I refused an invitation to MerrickesAmbulance close to Arras for I would very much like to see that city which the C.O. says is very interesting.
Entry.123:
A Sunday and the King's birthday. A gloriously fine day and one I would like to spend in the front line for the athmosphere is so clear.

As was to be expected it has been a great day in the air and the Huns have been fairly busy but it is no use saying anything to the contrary, our fellows have the Hun filled with dread for he does not return for we seem to have 3 planes for every one of his. We are daily expecting news of the great push up. Had a letter from Arnold Lack yesterday to say their men close to Armentieres & the 27th Field Ambulance is up there. Although it is 3 weeks today, no word re my transfer to that Ambulance. I wish something definite would come so that I might know just what to do.
Entry.124:
When we saw the birthday list of honours today I was just a tiny bit disappointed & surprised for there were just a few I did not expect who got honours & a few who were left sadly lamenting. They I do not know but I suppose it will always be so.

Even ourD.M.S. got nothing, our Colonel Maynard Smith, the Consulting Surgeon, nor our C.O. while GeorgeByrne got a D.S.O. I do not know much about his work but I hardly think he would get it unless for something fine although old George is a little bit casual. He is bitterly disappointed the C.O. did not receive an honour for he has worked as hard as any D.M.C. in uniform& has withtwo wonderfully fine nurses organised for all the stunts splendidly while his show has been one of the brightest posts anywhere the D.M.S. has always used ours as a show place & his turn will come one day.

June 5th

Today I had a visit from Col Toll. I only a couple of days ago that he heard from some of our Sisters that I was with the unit so promptly he rode over with his M.S. to see me.

He does not look a bit different although since having leaving New Guineahe has had a bad time with malaria& he has been twicewounded once rather seriously. 

Today we played 4th Corps Engineers, the match was quite exciting. They made 94 then we had 9 wickets for 93. I was last man in. I missed the first ball, the next was driven for a 2 & 
I
 had won the match. With my partner we knocked up to 103 & then he was bowled. They chaired me & I felt about as big as a threepenny bit.

June 6th

The C.O., Col Newland Smyth & Fooks went to Amiens today & left me in charge of the camp. Tonight I went over to Braithcourt to see Colonel Toll & had quite an enjoyable evening. It is a mighty long walk from here but to see such a great chap & to have a yarn about the old New Guinea days with the whitest men who went in that fire was worthit all. 

Wakened this morning to find myself immortalised in verse & also presented with a bat for having had the luck to make the winning stroke yesterday in a cricket match we played against 4th Corps Engineers. The poetry was not bad or the bat, quite a smart piece of work. The boys of the unit will have their bit of fun.

Heard the offensive up north started today.

June 7th

After an absence of exactly 4 weeks old Dickflew over tonight & dropped a very interesting letter. He is now stationed 12 miles W.N.W. of St. Quentin. He has told me he is due for leave in a couple of months & wants to know if I would get mine with his & that we might try to get away together. He suggested further France or Italy.

However I should like to know a little more definitely about Edna's arriving & so shall wait a while. Still it was good to see the dear old chap again for a bit. I know it must mean a lot to Vesyto know that he is well. Flying is a mighty seriousbusiness these days & every time they go up they risk their lives. Dick suggested flying back to Australia, buta bad idea. You could carry the pilot.



June 8th

The good news still comes in from the north & we are a little elated by it as I think our braveAustralians must have done all they were asked to do as is so usual.

It is really a remarkable thing for up to date I have hardly heard of one instance when they have failed. Our missions have always reached their objective but when the show has failed it has been due to failure of their flank supports which have always been Tommies.

Arnold found has been slipping ina few but they have distant & nameless. Our hasbeen with the night a few being Hun planes but mainly our wretched Archies. I think they should not be allowed to fireexcept in thedirectionof the German himself. We had a in a day or so as to who lost his& Archie died.

June 9th

The old Hun seems to have got more than he bargained for up at Messines & that the losses there must have been the greatest in the world. I should like to see the number afterwards. Fancy the amount of stuff that 450 tons of ammunitionwould .

I hope good old 3rd Division had its baptism of blood & it took all its objectives & also those of our 4th Division so that the 4th can move when the
Entry.125: should be our version. They were upon a time calledthe
Entry.126: the "neutrals" but they can hardly be that now. Sir Douglas Haigis reported to have said that this Messines show was the most successful stunt doneat any time in France. It is a fine thing for usto be associated with such an effort.
Entry.127:
This place just lately has hardly been done overfor with an Australian Division at rest round herethere has been plenty doing in the way of visitors. As soon as the news of Sister O'Dwyer's decoration got about I think practically every officer in the division must have made it his business to come & congratulate her formally. Although deservedly popular because of her brightness, still Sister would have been a great deal happier if they had written instead ofcoming because it is very difficult to entertain here.

The Australian mail went out today so I had to write up myletters which I could not finish last night & post them straightaway.
Entry.128:
This good work up north continues & I am gladtoo because the old Kaiser about a week ago had the cheek to say that our offensive was finished. It must have given him a sickening blow to find that the Messines ridge which absolutely dominated the Ypres & Armentieres sector of the line is now his no longer.

Wrote to Dick today to say I was sorry I could not give him a definite answer re leave. I thought possibly that a reply to my cable would arrive today but it did not. 

Had a little party tonight to celebrate the arrival of Sister O'Dwyer's Red Cross. If any girl within A.A.N.S. deserved it I am sure she did for she has done wonderfully fine work. We are ahappy family here nowalthough the great bulk of us arenot young.
Entry.129:
Had a visit today from Sir William Hensingham consulting physician to the C.S.S.s in France. He is greatly interested in the awfully common disease known as P.U.O. which is in my opinion a remittent fever due most probably to a protozoan parasite in the blood. An investigator seems to have found fairly conclusively that the louse is the carrier. However I have arranged with the C.O. to have a special ward for those cases & as far as possible I am going to see at any rate clinically what can be done. He agrees with me that the parasite is protozoan & now he has put up a special case to the D.G. asking that a special be sent over to investigate & do special work on the blood of these patients.

I shall keep regular charts of them all & note downanything extraordinary.
Entry.130:
Had a visit this afternoon from Jack Barton who used to be Superingon the . He was looking mighty well & we had a good old yarn about old times. He was saying that there was an honour board up on the old with the names of all those who had gone out on service. It was great to have a yarn with him because it is a very long while since I had any news about some good pals I made in the old ship. I was disgusted when he told me that B.Rs had made no provision for any of their permanent staff who had volunteered. B.Rs made a tremendous splash about patriotism but there are dozens of men who have done their bit by their employers staff. Jack said that Chursenwas going out tomorrow & the old second were coming back.

Old has been freed to abdicate himself.
Entry.131:
We are still worrying about our Australian mail for it was 3 weeks yesterday since we had an Australian mail & I am just wondering when we shall have our next.

Heard a vile rumour said to have come through the Bank of N.S.W. that our mail has gone down. Capt Bodham, A.D.C. to one of our generals, told us today & he was telling us that the Hun was retiring up north & that our advanced were some thousand yards or so ahead & had not made contact with him. Also that the art treasureswere being removed from Lille by the Hun & very probably he will retire there quite shortly. Oh it is a great war but I wish that it would soon end for all of us.

At midnight had a gas alarm & the old Hun put over gas but it did not do us any harm.
Entry.132:
Grandma's Birthday today. I hope the cable which she should have received last Monday arrived in time.

Head today from most reliable source that Sir Douglas Haig believes that the war will be over in November. Well if he is right we shall not be a bit disappointed & even if I am wrong when I say it will be over by the end of the summer, it is better to be two months out & somewhere near it than to go about with a big face & say that the last 7 years of the war will be the worst. There is no doubt that a cheerful face and one that can still smile even when it looks as if the Russians were not playing the game is worth a mighty lot.

A mighty successful Hun raid on London yesterday, bad luck to them about 100 killed & 450 wounded.
Entry.133:
A delightful day today but we got it in the neck today. Fifth Corps had a stunt which gave such a lot of casualties that we had to take the overflow. Between 9 & 4 we got in over 300 & then switched to 29 C.C.S. This kept us going solidly as then the operating commenced. Out of this little lot we have 61 ops to do & that I am certain it will mean an all night sitting for us.

Poor old Johnnie Smyth is still right sick & his is not getting a bit better. Looks to me as if he is in for a bad time.

After giving a diphtheria throat myself a few days ago,I was greatly relieved today when the report came back today negative.
Entry.134:
We eventually cleaned up our 61 ops of which Bill & I did 23 at least & then I toddled off to bed at 6 a.m., he had the four tables going all night. The sad part about the show was that we were successful at the two flanks but the centre was held up & we had to come back.

A rash came out on poor old John Smyth today & we have had to send him off to isolation with scarletfever. His is a slightly atypical case but it is pretty definite. Poor beggar he has had no luck because with bronchitis, trench fever & mumps, scarlet, he has practically run the lot of so called infectious diseases.

Had General Wisdom in to tea today & he says the war will be over by September. Unfortunately I did not get a chance to ask him his reasons.
Entry.135:
I was so tired & lazy yesterday after an all night sitting that I did not write any of my usual Sunday letters.

I half expected I would get a cable from Edna today but up to date nothing has turned up. I would dearly love to know if she has left Australia.

I do not know what has happened to the mails because today the men got their Melbourne letters up to & including May 1st while I got Sydney & Adelaide papers of similar date but never a line from anyone. I wonder if the mail has gone astray or if our mail is the last to be sorted. Now we have practically no Victoria officers there is no mail for the officers while there is plenty for the men.
Entry.136:
Yesterday was the 102 Anniverwary of the battle of Waterloo,while present indications point tothe lowcountry once again becoming the cockpit of Europe.

The success of the Messines push & the news I heard today that the french had placed the Belgians north of us & also that our George had gone up there with mobsto make a big push with 20 division between Ypres & the sea makes it looking possible that the next fighting will be there.

The padre next door assures me that the preliminary bombardment started there last Sunday. Up to date we have had no news of it in the papers & Colonel Gray, our new consulting surgeon, knows nothing of it.
Entry.137:
The C.O. asked me today if I would like my English leave in the near future or if I would prefer to wait a while to see if Edna comes over & I decided to wait. At least in a week or two I shall have her letters or else some more cables telling me something definite. Still no news of the position of the mail why we still do not know. Heard today that the submarine sinkings have once again gone up & might beexplained I suppose by the poor weather & the long nights.

Had a field card from Arnold Lack saying he goes O.K. & also a letter fromFrank Mitchellasking for a transfer.

I wonderhow many new books I shall fill because when I left I thought it would be a couple at most. But I must be patient.
